awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Causes and Consequences of the Gradients in the Vertical Plasma Drift in the Equatorial Plasma Drift Vortex
awd_abstract_narration:
At low latitudes during the evening twilight period, as the E-region plasma recombines due to fast chemistry, a strong vertical gradient in the plasma density will appear below the F-region peak height. This vertical drift gradient in altitude below the F peak can be surprising large, dynamic, and variable from day-to-day. This award would apply a physics-based model of the ionosphere-thermosphere-electric field to study the relationship between the development of these vertical gradients and a possible production of plasma bubble structure.  In these circumstances the phenomenon of unstable plasma fluids that occur whenever a dense fluid overlies a light fluid will generate strange three-dimensional structures. These plasma depletion regions (often called "bubbles") affect severely communications of radio waves that normally are reflected off the smooth bottom side of the F-region plasma layer. The data that would be used in this study are derived from observations by the Jicamarca Radio Observatory and by the Low Latitude Ionosphere Sensor Network (LISN) network of total electron content and ionosonde measurements of plasma density throughout South America.  Also associated with LISN data are equatorial magnetometer measurements that can be interpreted to produce estimates of upward vertical plasma drift rates during the evening period. These results would be used to explore the day-to-day variability of the gradients to help develop a better understanding of the relationship between the rate of vertical drift and the onset of equatorial plasma bubble production. UTD will be utilizing a graduate student to accomplish much of the data analysis and modeling.

Large equatorial plasma bubbles (EPBs), which are associated with the strongest signal scintillations, have negative impacts on communication and navigation technologies. Society has become dependent on these technologies to accomplish common tasks in transportation services, industrial ventures, and military operations. In addition to addressing these important science questions for the mitigation of negative impacts of F-region plasma structures, these activities will continue and expand multinational collaborations associated with the LISN Project and the JRO.

INTRODUCTION AND BENEFITS OF RESEARCH

The work was a collaboration of experienced scientists to improve the understanding of the electric fields in the earth's ionosphere. The ionosphere is the component of the Earth's upper atmosphere (above 90 km altitude) where the sun's most energetic radiation ionizes the neutral gases of the atmosphere. This creates a region of dense free electrons and ions called the ionosphere. The ionosphere influences many technologies that are used for navigation and communication. For example, the Global Positioning System (GPS) location technology for cell phones, automobiles, trains, ships, and airplanes depends on a quality connection between the vehicle GPS devices and the constellation of GPS satellites orbiting the earth. The ionosphere can have strong turbulence in the density of free electrons, which can negatively impact the performance of GPS devices. This study was designed to improve our understanding and modeling capabilities of the ionosphere and the occurrence of turbulence in the ionosphere. 

DESCRIPTION OF RESEARCH

The density of electrons and ions in the ionosphere is created by ionizing solar radiation but the subsequent movement of the ionized gas is controlled by atmospheric winds and ionospheric electric fields generated by the atmospheric winds pushing the electrons and ions through the Earth's strong magnetic field. These electric fields are modeled within a complex coupled-modeling system that takes into account (1) the earth's neutral atmosphere, (2) the solar ionization of the earth's atmosphere, (3) the chemistry of these neutral, ion, and electron gases, (3) the production of neutral gas winds in the atmosphere, (4) the earth's magnetic field structure, and (5) the currents generated by the neutral winds moving the charged particles (ions and electrons). This large, coupled modeling system attempts to correctly reproduce structure of the ionosphere and indicate when the ionosphere is unstable for turbulent conditions that can disrupt navigation and communication technologies. 

Figure 1 plots the global peak density of free electrons in the earth's ionosphere at 00:00 Universal Time on a day in November 2018. The electron density structure is calculated by an ionosphere called the Ionosphere Forecast Model. The yellow line indicates where the solar terminator divides day and night conditions. The daytime shows increased electron density, but the electric fields cause the ion-electron gas to move up in altitude near the Earth's magnetic equator (close to the Earth's geographic equator) and away from the magnetic equator during the day. This generates the low-latitude feature called the Equatorial Ionization Anomaly (EIA) of elevated electron density. The EIA persists into the nighttime but also continually decreases through the night. 

This study coupled the Ionospheric Forecast Model with models of the neutral atmosphere density and winds to generate these electric fields within the physics-based Electric Field Model (EFM). The EFM is designed to model the low and mid-latitude electric fields that produce the EIA anomalies and smaller structures related to turbulence. Figure 2 plots a cross section of the several parameters of the ionosphere near the earth's equator. The left panel plots the integrated electron density of the ionosphere in altitude above the earth (ZEQ) during the afternoon and early evening (Solar Local Time ? SLT). The sun sets a bit after 18:00SLT. The center panel plots the vertical velocity of the electron-ion gases due to electric fields (red is upward, blue is downward). The right panel shows the ionosphere density drifting upward soon after sunset (18:00 to 19:00SLT) due to an electric field feature called the Prereversal Enhancement (PRE) of the electric field. The PRE is an intensification of the electric field just after sunset which causes the ion-electron gas to drift upwards with increased velocity before the electric field and drift velocity reverses direction for a night long downward drift. The right panel plots the likelihood of ionosphere turbulence (red is unstable conditions, blue is stable conditions). As the ionosphere drifts upward during the PRE, it becomes unstable and strong turbulence often develops in the ion-electron gas. The turbulence occurence has been very difficult to predict with models. 

The results of this effort demonstrated that it is necessary to correctly model the detailed altitude structure of the vertical ionosphere drift (Figure 2 middle panel) to correctly determine the growth rate of ionospheric instabilities. The EFM was released for use by scientists to improve other modeling efforts. This is an important step towards forecasting of turbulent conditions that can impact GPS navigation and radio frequency communications.
